column4: YO! Whilst in the command line, when I enter a long string of characters, how can I instantly jump to the very front of the line?
ctl-a should do it
you've done a lot for this community, thank you
how long did it take you to learn everything
someday I expect to be competent
but probably after a year or so I knew enough to know how to answer my own questions
how long ago was that first year... just curious, I remember seeing you here quite some years ago
my first ever linux install? March 19, 2000 :)
what continent are you located on?
Los Angeles CA
no, I know no one personally. Just enjoy helping out. You might like #ubuntu-california , there's a loco team with some members in OC
thanks I'll scope it
how can I alias a executable file? The only way I've been able to figure out how to run it is with the guis
add a line to your .bashrc , for example   alias  ac='/usr/bin/apt-cache'   When you log in, the alias will automatically be there
will I be able to use it instantly?
no. but, if you type   source ~/.bashrc , your shell will re-read the file and then you'll have access
thanks

it returned ' error while loading shared libraries: libjemalloc.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory'; is there another command to "run" a file, like a shell script or executable?
I'm not sure what you did there. what command gave that error?
alias songbird='/home/sagredo/Songbird/songbird-bin'
but if you do    cd /home/sagredoSongbird && ./songbird-bin, it runs?
with the right cd dir, of course
that, however, does not work when I alias the command, any suggestions?
nevermind, I was directing it to the wrong file when I wrote the alias command, it's working
